indDescEn:
This indicator shows the total government revenue, expressed as % of Gross domestic product (GDP). This refers to the total income a government receives.
The general government sector comprises central government, state government, local government, and social security funds.

This indicator shows the total government expenditure, expressed as % of Gross domestic product (GDP). This refers to the total amount of money a government spends.
The general government sector comprises central government, state government, local government, and social security funds.

indLongName: GDP per capita in Purchasing Power Standards  (PPS)
indDescEn:
This indicator shows the Gross domestic product (GDP), expressed per capita in Purchasing Power Standards (PPS), in relation to the European Union (EU28) average which is set to equal 100.
GDP is a measure of economic activity and is defined as the value of all goods and services produced less the value of any goods or services used for their creation.
If the index of this indicator of a country is higher than 100, this country's level of GDP per capita is higher than the EU average and vice versa.
PPS is a common currency that eliminates the differences in price levels between countries allowing meaningful comparisons of GDP between countries. Thus one PPS buys the same volume of goods and services in all countries.

This indicator shows the inflation rate, i.e. the average price change (in %) from one year to another. Inflation is an increase in the general price level of goods and services.
When there is inflation in an economy, the value of money decreases because a given amount will buy fewer goods and services than before.
Inflation in an economy is often calculated by examining a basket of goods and services and comparing the changes in the prices of that basket over time.
A negative inflation rate shows deflation which is a decrease in the general price level of goods and services and represents an increase in the value of money.

indUnit: % change of total employment compared to previous year
indDescEn:
This indicator shows the change (in %) from one year to another of the total number of employed persons in a country .
Employed persons comprise persons aged 15 years and more who either worked for at least one hour for pay or profit or family gain during the reference week or who were not at work during the reference week, but had a job or business from which they were temporarily absent. It covers employees and self-employed.

This indicator shows the general government gross debt, also known as public debt, expressed as % of Gross domestic product (GDP).
It is the nominal (face) value of total gross debt outstanding at the end of the year and consolidated between and within the government subsectors. It includes outstanding stocks of currency and deposits, debt securities and loans at the end of the reference period.
The general government sector comprises central government, state government, local government, and social security funds.

This indicator shows the government deficit / surplus, expressed as % of Gross domestic product (GDP).
It is the difference between the revenue and the expenditure of the general government sector. If expenditure is higher than revenue the government registers a deficit, while if revenue is higher than expenditure it will record a surplus.
The general government sector comprises central government, state government, local government, and social security funds.

This indicator shows investments (also called "Gross fixed capital formation" ), expressed as % of Gross domestic product (GDP).
Investments consist of resident producersÂ« acquisitions (e.g. purchases), minus disposals (e.g. sales), of fixed tangible or intangible assets. Fixed tangible assets cover in particular machinery and equipment, vehicles, dwellings and other buildings, but also cultivated assets such as livestock for breeding and vineyards. It also covers intangible assets, such as computer software and entertainment, literary or artistic originals.

indShortName: Household consumption expenditure:  Food & non-alcoholic beverages
indLongName: Final consumption expenditure of households:  Food & non-alcoholic beverages
indDescEn:
This indicator shows household expenditure for food & non-alcoholic beverages, expressed as % of total household expenditure.
It refers to any spending done by a person living alone or by a group of people living together in shared accommodation and with common expenses for the direct satisfaction of individual needs. It refers to purchases for consumption at home only (not in hotel, restaurants, bars, kiosks, etc.).
Food & non-alcoholic beverages comprise bread, meat, dairy products, fruits & vegetables etc. and coffee, tea, water, juices etc.

indLongName: Final consumption expenditure of households: Clothing & footwear
indDescEn:
This indicator shows household expenditure for clothing & footwear, expressed as % of total household expenditure.
It refers to any spending done by a person living alone or by a group of people living together in shared accommodation and with common expenses for the direct satisfaction of individual needs.
Clothing comprises clothes for everyday wear, sport or work, including also e.g. belts, hats, accessories for making clothing & dry-cleaning and repair. Footwear refers to all footwear, including sports footwear suitable for everyday or leisure wear, as well as repair.

This indicator shows the number of inhabitants of a country on 1 January (or, in some cases, on 31 December of the previous year). The population is based on data from the most recent census adjusted by the components of population change produced since the last census, or based on population registers.

This indicator shows the likely future size of the total population in 2080.
This is an 'what-if scenario' that aim to provide information about the likely future size and age structure of the population based on assumptions of future trends in fertility, life expectancy and migration.

This indicator shows the median age of the total population. The median age is the age that divides the population of the country into two equal groups, that is, half the people are younger than this age and half are older.
This indicator shows the population aged 15-24 years, expressed as % of the total population.
This indicator shows the population aged 80 years or older, expressed as % of the total population.
This indicator shows the number of inhabitants per square kilometre.

indUnit: Mean number of children per woman
indDescEn:
This indicator shows the average number of children that would be born alive to a woman during her lifetime if she was to pass through her childbearing years conforming to the age-specific fertility rates of a given year.
In order to keep the population size constant in the absence of migration flows a fertility rate of 2.1 is needed.

This indicator shows the employment rate of people aged 20-64 . It is the share of employed persons aged 20-64 in relation to the total population of the same age group.
Employed persons comprise persons who either worked for at least one hour for pay or profit or family gain during the reference week or who were not at work during the reference week but had a job or business from which they were temporarily absent. It covers employees and self-employed. This is measured according to the definition of the International Labour Organisation (ILO).

This indicator shows the unemployment rate of young people aged 15-24 years. It expresses the number of young unemployed persons as a share (%) of the labour force of the same age.
Unemployed persons are those who (1) were without work during the reference week, but are currently available for work and (2) who were either actively seeking work in the past four weeks or who had already found a job to start within the next three months.
The labour force comprises employed and unemployed persons. This is measured according to the definition of the International Labour Organisation (ILO).
This indicator shows the number of years a person aged 15 is expected to be active in the labour market (i.e. in employment) throughout his/her life.

This indicator shows the ratio of the number of marriages during the year to the average population in that year. The value is expressed per 1000 inhabitants.
A marriage is the act, ceremony or process by which the legal relationship between two persons is formed. The legality of the union may be established by civil, religious or other means as recognised by the laws of each country.

This indicator shows the ratio of the number of divorces during the year to the average population in that year. The value is expressed per 1000 inhabitants.
A divorce is the final legal dissolution (ending) of a marriage, according to the laws of each country. Divorce is possible in all European Union Member States.
This indicator shows the average number of years a new-born male child can expect to live if subjected throughout his life to the current mortality conditions.
This indicator shows the average number of years a new-born female child can expect to live if subjected throughout her life to the current mortality conditions.
This indicator shows the ratio of the number of deaths of children under one year of age to the number of live births in the reference year. The value is expressed per 1000 live births.

indLongName: Average number of persons per household
indDescEn:
The indicator shows the average number of persons living in private households.
A private household is an entity having common arrangements, sharing household expenses or daily needs, living in a shared common residence.
This indicator shows young men aged 18-34 years living with their parent(s) in a common household, expressed as % of the total population of the same age group.
This indicator shows young women aged 18-34 years living with their parent(s) in a common household, expressed as % of the total population of the same age group.

This indicator shows the total number of asylum applicants during the year.
An asylum applicant means a person having submitted an application for international protection or having been included in such application as a family member during the reference period. Application for international protection means an application for international protection, irrespective of whether the application was lodged on arrival at border, or from inside the country, and irrespective of whether the person entered the territory legally (e.g. as a tourist) or illegally.

This indicator shows the number of students aged 20 to 24 who are enrolled in tertiary education, expressed as % of the total population aged 20 to 24.
Tertiary education comprises programmes with academic orientation, which are largely theoretical and programmes with an occupational orientation, as well as tertiary studies that lead to an advanced research qualification (Ph.D. or doctorate).

This indicator shows the total number of bed-places in hotels, holiday and other short-stay accommodation, camping grounds, recreational vehicle parks and trailer parks.
The number of bed places do not include extra beds that may be set up upon customer request. The term bed place applies to a single bed, a double bed is counted as two bed places.

indLongName: Persons never having used the internet
indDescEn: This indicator shows persons aged 16-74 years, expressed as % of all persons aged 16-74 , who have never used the internet.

This indicator shows households with broadband access, expressed as % of all households with at least one member aged 16-74 in the country.
The availability of broadband is measured by the percentage of households that are connectable to an exchange that has been converted to support xDSL-technology, to a cable network upgraded for internet traffic, or to other broadband technologies. It includes fixed and mobile connections.

indLongName: Persons who used the internet for internet banking
indDescEn:
This indicator shows persons aged 16-74 years, expressed as % of all persons aged 16-74, who have used the internet for internet banking within the last 3 months.
Internet banking includes electronic transactions with a bank for payment etc. or for looking up account information.

indLongName: Persons using the internet to order goods or services
indDescEn: This indicator shows persons aged 16-74 years, expressed as % of all persons aged 16-74, who have bought or ordered goods and/or services online for private use within the last 12 months.

This indicator shows the evolution of the output and activity of the construction sector, expressed as % change compared to the previous year. Construction includes building construction and civil engineering.

This indicator shows the livestock of the cattle population in each country, expressed in 1000 animals, in December of the year.
'Cattle' means bovine animals, such as calves, bullocks, bulls, heifers and cows.
This indicator shows the amount of cheese produced, expressed in 1000 tons. It covers all types of cheese, e.g. soft and hard cheese, cheese obtained from goats', cows', ewes' milk etc.

This indicator shows the livestock of the dairy cow population in each country, expressed in 1000 animals, in December of the year.
A dairy cow is a cow kept exclusively or principally for the production of milk for human consumption and/or other dairy products.
This indicator shows the pig population in each country, expressed in 1000 animals, in December of the year.

indLongName: Share of imports by Member State
indUnit: % of total EU imports from the Extra-EU
indDescEn: This indicator shows the share of each Member State in total EU imports of goods from countries outside the EU (= Extra-EU).

indLongName: Share of exports by Member State
indUnit: % of total EU exports to the Extra-EU
indDescEn: This indicator shows the share of each Member State in total EU exports of goods to countries outside the EU (= Extra-EU).
This indicators shows the trade balance, meaning the value of exports of goods minus the value of imports of goods, expressed in million of euros.

This indicator shows the total number of passengers carried by plane in the country, covering arrivals plus departures.
This means that for example, a person flying from Paris to London will be counted in France as a 'departure passenger' and in the United Kingdom as an 'arrival passenger'. However, the value of the EU excludes double-counting, i.e. not counting the same passengers twice. It excludes direct transit passengers.

This indicator shows the carriage of goods by road, expressed as % of all inland transport modes (road, rail and inland waterways) in tonne-kilometres (tkm).
Tkm is a unit of measure of freight transport which represents the movement of one tonne of goods by a given transport mode over a distance of one kilometre. Road transport is based on all movements of vehicles registered in the reporting country.

indLongName: Electricity prices for medium sized household consumers (between 2500 and 5000 kWh)
indUnit: EUR per kWh, including taxes and levies
indDescEn:
This indicator shows the prices charged to a household with an annual consumption of between 2 500 and 5 000 kWh, including taxes and levies.
The final price charged to electricity customers will depend on the structure of electricity tariffs and contracts which normally contain a number of factors, including fixed charges and unit prices that vary according to the amount of electricity and the time of day it is consumed.

indLongName: Electricity prices for medium sized industrial consumers (between 500 and 2000 MWh)
indUnit: EUR per kWh, including taxes and levies
indDescEn:
This indicator shows the prices charged to an industrial consumer with an annual consumption between 500 and 2000 MWh, including taxes and levies.
The final price charged to electricity customers will depend on the structure of electricity tariffs and contracts which normally contain a number of factors, including fixed charges and unit prices that vary according to the amount of electricity and the time of day it is consumed.

This indicator shows the share of electricity produced from renewable energy sources of total gross national electricity consumption for a given calendar year.
Thus, it measures the contribution of electricity produced from renewable energy sources to the national electricity consumption.
Electricity produced from renewable energy sources comprises the electricity generation from hydro plants (excluding pumping), wind, solar, geothermal and electricity from biomass/wastes.
Gross national electricity consumption comprises the total gross national electricity generation from all fuels, plus electricity imports, minus exports.

This indicator shows the share of energy from renewable energy sources in gross final energy consumption.
It refers to renewable energy delivered to final consumers (industry, transport, households, services including public services, agriculture, forestry and fisheries) and covers solar thermal and photovoltaic energy, hydro (including tide, wave and ocean energy), wind, geothermal energy and biomass (including biological waste and liquid biofuels).
Gross final energy consumption of all energy sources covers total energy delivered for energy purposes to final consumers as well as the transmission and distribution losses for electricity and heat.

This indicator shows the amount of municipal waste generated per person.
Municipal waste consists to a large extent of waste generated by households, but may also include similar wastes generated by small businesses and public institutions and collected by the municipality, this part of municipal waste may vary from municipality to municipality and from country to country, depending on the local waste management system. For areas not covered by a municipal waste collection scheme the amount of waste generated is estimated. Waste from agriculture and industry is not included.

This indicator shows is the environmental tax revenue of the general government sector expressed as share of total revenues from all taxes and social contributions of general government.
An environmental tax is a tax whose tax base is a physical unit (or a proxy of it) of something that has a proven, specific negative impact on the environment. This includes e.g. taxes on energy products for transport purposes, such as petrol, diesel, etc., on energy products for stationary purposes, such as natural gas, coal, coke etc., on pollution, covering measured or estimated emissions to air and water, waste management, etc.

indLongName: High-tech patent applications to the European Patent Office
indDescEn:
This indicator shows the number of high-tech patent applications to the European Patent Office.
A patent is an intellectual property right, a public title of industrial property that gives its owner the exclusive right to use his/her invention in the technical field for a limited number of years. Patents reflect a country's inventive activity. Patents also show the country's capacity to exploit knowledge and translate it into potential economic gains.
A patent application needs to be for an invention, i.e. a new solution to a technical problem which satisfies the criteria of novelty, inventiveness, industrial applicability.
A patent may be granted to a firm, an individual or a public body by a patent office.
It remains valid in a given country or area for a limited period of time. The technical fields which are defined as high-technology groups are: aviation, communication technology, computer and automated business equipment, lasers, micro-organism and genetic engineering, semiconductors.

This indicator shows the expenditure on research and development (R&D), expressed as percentage of GDP (called 'R&D intensity').
R&D refers to creative work undertaken on a systematic basis in order to increase the stock of knowledge (including knowledge of man, culture and society), and the use of this knowledge to devise new applications.

indUnit: % of total exports to third countries
indDescEn:
This indicator shows exports of high-tech products to the Extra-EU28 (i.e. countries outside the EU28), expressed as % of total exports to the Extra-EU28.
High technology products are the sum of the following products: aerospace, computers-office machines, electronics-telecommunications, pharmacy, Scientific instruments, electrical machinery, chemistry, non-electrical machinery, armament.
A detailed list of high-tech products can be found here: http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/cache/metadata/Annexes/htec_esms_an5.pdf
